courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Immersion Experience I
courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with opportunities to study and use English in a first language context while engaging themselves with the English culture, thus resulting in gains in language, professional and personal development. The course will be conducted in the format of a study programme to be conducted overseas. The course will include components such as language enhancement, English language teaching techniques, cultural orientation and school experience or the equivalent.
courses.component:
Classwork

Field Studies/Field-trip
Independent Study
Lecture
Others

Workshop
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. English language enhancement
2. English language teaching methodology and education
3. Academic English skills
4. School experience
5. Social programme / cultural activities
6. Self-directed learning
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: course-end evaluation questionnaires
2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via e-mail, telephone or face-to-face chat
3. Report from course provider
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Freed, B.F. (1995). Second language acquisition in a study context abroad. Philadelphia, Pa.: J. Benjamins.
2. Hyland, K. (2006). English for academic purposes: an advanced resource book. London: Routledge
3. MacIntyre, P., Baker, S., Clément, R., & Conrod, S. (2001). Willingness to communicate, social support, and language-learning orientations of immersion students. Studies in Second Language Acquisition, 23(3), 369-388.
4. Pollard, Andrew; Collins, Janet; Simco, Neil; Swaffield, Sue; Warin, Jo and Warwick, Paul (2002). Reflective Teaching: Effective and Evidence-Informed Professional Practice. UK: Continuum.
5. Zeichner, K., Liston, D. (2014). Reflective Teaching. New York: Routledge.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Immersion Experience II
courses.description: This course builds on and further extends knowledge and experiences gained in Immersion Experience I. It is conducted in the format of a study programme to be conducted in an overseas country where English is used as the first language. The course will include components such as language enhancement, English language teaching techniques, cultural orientation and school experience or the equivalent. The school experience component will help broaden students' perspectives on education and on language teaching and learning in a different cultural context.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Immersion Experience III
courses.description: This course builds on and further extends knowledge and experiences gained in Immersion Experience I and II. The course will be conducted in the format of an integrated English language programme to be held in an English as a first language context. In addition to components such as language enhancement, English language teaching techniques, cultural orientation and school experience, this course offers an opportunity for students to enhance their academic reading, writing and speaking skills to successfully complete academic tasks.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Theory and Methodology
courses.description: This course provides a theoretical foundation to the understanding of English language teaching methodology. Selective methods used in teaching English to non-native speakers in Hong Kong and abroad will be examined. Students will become familiar with the principles governing the curriculum design and implementation of the different English teaching methods. Methods appropriate to child, adolescent, and young adult learners are discussed and demonstrated. Input from the course forms the knowledge base for subsequent courses on English language teaching techniques. Observation of videotapes of lessons and opportunities for peer teaching will be included.
courses.component:
Discussion
Independent Study
Lecture
Others
Seminar

courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will have:

1. a better understanding of

(i) issues involved in analysing teaching practices

(ii) theories underlying teaching practices

(iii) how historical and alternative methods and approaches impact on the communicative teaching of English

2. developed and applied a framework for the analysis and evaluation of teaching practices in Hong Kong classrooms
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theories of second language acquisition

2. Factors affecting second language learning

3. Approaches and methods in language teaching

4. Teaching English language to learners of different age groups

5. Learning culture

6. Learning style and strategies

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via consultation, e-mail, telephone or face-to-face chat

2. Harmer, J. 2007. The Practice of English Language Teaching. (4th edition) London: Longman.

3. Howatt, A.P.R. with H. G. Widdowson. 2004. The history of English language teaching. (2nd edition) Oxford: Oxford University Press.

4. Johnson, K. 2001. An introduction to foreign language learning and teaching. Harlow: Longman.

8. Richards, J. and T. Rodgers. 2001. Approaches and Methods in Language Teaching. (2nd edition). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

9. Widdowson, H. 2003. Defining issues in English language teaching. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

10. Willis, J. 1996. A Framework for Task-based Learning. Harlow: Longman.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Techniques I
courses.description: This is the first course of a series of three related courses on practices and techniques of teaching English in Hong Kong schools. These three courses seek to help students develop their theories and practices of language pedagogy and awareness of options available in the language classroom, make informed decisions in the planning and teaching processes and reflect on their teaching styles. Throughout the three courses, special attention will be paid to English language teaching pedagogy for current local curricular developments. These courses will include opportunities for observation of videotaped lessons and peer teaching. The first course focuses on developing the general competency, knowledge, strategies and skills a teacher needs in order to organise effective learning in the language classroom under the aegis of a communicative approach to language teaching and learning. A wide range of techniques and teaching strategies suitable for learners of different ages, proficiency levels and learning needs will be included. Topics include lesson planning, motivating, engaging and interacting with learners, classroom organization and management, dealing with errors, classroom language and using and evaluating learning materials. Teaching of grammar and vocabulary will also be covered.

courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

1. demonstrate an understanding of the current principles and practice of teaching English as a foreign / second language;
2. have developed knowledge, skills and techniques to organise effective teaching of English to learners of different ages and proficiency levels in a classroom setting; and

3. have developed knowledge, skills and techniques to teach grammar and vocabulary to learners of different ages and proficiency levels.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Teaching techniques and teaching strategies suitable for learners of different ages, proficiency levels and learning needs

2. Lesson planning

3. Strategies for motivating, engaging and interacting with learners

4. Classroom organization and management

5. Teaching of grammar and dealing with errors

6. Teaching of vocabulary

7. Evaluating grammar and vocabulary instructional materials

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Techniques II
courses.description: This course focuses on the teaching of listening and speaking skills. It is designed to develop students' knowledge, strategies and skills for teaching listening and speaking to learners of different proficiency levels and learning needs. The theoretical basis for current practice and the 'how' and the 'what' of teaching these two skills will be examined, demonstrated and practised. Teaching of pronunciation and phonics will also be covered.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Techniques III
courses.description: This course focuses on the teaching of reading and writing skills. It is designed to develop students' knowledge, strategies and skills for teaching reading and writing to learners of different proficiency levels and learning needs. The theoretical basis for current practice and the 'how' and the 'what' of teaching these two skills will be examined, demonstrated and practicsed. Teaching of integrated skills will also be covered.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Language Assessment and Evaluation
courses.description: This course presents the basic principles of language assessment and current practices. It aims to develop a sound understanding of theoretical foundations and key issues of second language assessment, equip students with knowledge and practical skills in language test design, and provide opportunities to evaluate and critique language tests.

3. Test construction

5. Feedback for effective student learning

6. Critique of language tests

7. Critical discussion and reflection on language assessment in real classroom contexts

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Studying Second Language Learners and Classrooms
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to classroom-based research, with a view to sensitizing students to the complexity of language learning in the classroom, and equipping them with the skills of collecting and analysing language teaching and learning data. Major research methods in language teaching, in particular action research, are covered. Under the guidance of a supervisor, students will develop a research proposal during the course and collect data during their teaching practice.
courses.component:
Discussion
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Others
Seminar
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Types of classroom-based research
2. Selecting and developing a topic for investigation
3. Generating research questions
4. The ‘why’ and ‘how’ of literature review
5. Research design and methodology
6. Data collection methods
7. Data analysis methods
8. Write up of a proposal for an investigative study
9. Academic literacy

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Project Report
courses.description: This course builds on the prerequisite course entitled ‘Studying Second Language Learners and Classroom’, which provides an introduction to classroom-based research. Course participants have already prepared a research proposal for the prerequisite course. Under the guidance of a supervisor, they will undertake the research project that they have proposed during the teaching practicum and submit a report on the study for course assessment. The aim of the two courses is to provide course participants, who are student teachers of English as a second language, an opportunity to conduct a study in the classroom for a better understanding of the teacher, the learners and classroom teaching and learning.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Materials Development and Adaptation
courses.description: Given that effective instructional materials are able to enrich learning experience and enhance learners' attention engagement in classrooms, this course aims to equip students with the principles and skills of materials development (materials design, selection, adaptation and evaluation) for ELT through lectures, group discussions and workshops. The following topics will be included: (a) an overview of different language learning models and instructional principles for formulating materials design principles that suit students' future teaching contexts; (b) the relationship between instructional methods, syllabus, and instructional materials; (c) the use of ELT instructional materials such as text books, authentic materials and multimedia materials; (d) materials selection, adaptation and evaluation. Throughout the course, students will be provided with practical experience of evaluating and adapting text books, and designing tasks requiring the use of authentic / multimedia materials in classrooms.
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Issues and trends in materials development Understanding language curriculum

2. instructional design; needs assessment

3. Material evaluation

4. Technology in material development

5. Materials for teaching Grammar

6. Materials for teaching Vocabulary

7. Materials for developing Reading skills

8. Materials for developing Writing skills

9. Materials for developing Speaking skills

10. Materials for developing Listening skills
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: mid-term and/or course-end evaluation questionnaires

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via consultation, e-mail, telephone or face-to-face chat
courses.required_readings: Tomlinson, B. (Ed.). (2013). Developing materials for language teaching. (2nd edition). Bloomsbury Academic.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Bourke, J. M. (2006). 'Designing a topic-based syllabus for young learners'. ELT Journal. 60/3:279-286.

2. Chambers, F. (1997). 'Seeking consensus in coursebook evaluation'. ELT Journal. 51/1:29-35.

3. Clarke, D. F. (1989). Material adaptation: why leave it all to the teacher? ELT Journal 43/2, 133-41.

4. Cunningsworth, Alan. (1985). Evaluating and selecting EFL teaching material. Oxford: Heinemann.

5. Cunningsworth, Alan. (1995). Choosing your course book. Macmillan Education.

6. Dubin, F. and Olshtain, E (1986). Course design: developing programs and materials for language learning. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

7. Ellis, R. (1997). 'The empirical evaluation of language teaching materials'. ELT Journal. 51/1:36-47.

8. Gilmore, A. (2004). 'A comparison of textbook and authentic interactions'. ELT Journal. 58/4:363-374.

9. Graves, Kathleen. (1996). Teachers as course developers. Cambridge University Press.

10. Graves, Kathleen. (1999). Designing language courses: A guide for teachers. Boston, MA: Heinle & Heinle.

11. McDonough, Jo and Shaw, Christopher. 2003. Materials and Methods in ELT: a teacher's guide. Malden, MA; Oxford: Blackwell.

12. McGrath, Ian. 2002. Materials Evaluation and Design for Language Teaching. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press.

13. Morton, R. (1999). 'Abstracts as authentic material for EAP classes'. ELT Journal. 53/3:177-1.

14. Nitta, R and Gardner, S (2005). 'Consciousness-raising and practice in ELT coursebooks'. ELT Journal. 59/1:3-13.

15. Peacock, M. (1997). 'The effect of authentic materials on the motivation of EFL learner'. ELT Journal. 51/2: 144-155.

16. Richards, J. (1994). 'Beyond the text book: The role of commercial materials in language teaching'. RELC Journal. 24/1:1-14.

17. Richards, J and Mahoney, D. (1996). Teachers and textbooks: a survey of beliefs and practices. Perspectives, 8.1 (Working Papers of the Department of English, City University, Hong Kong), pp.40-63.

18. Richards, Jack and Rodgers, Theodore S. (2001). Approaches and Methods in Language Teaching: a description and analysis. (2nd ed.) Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

19. Richards, J. (2001). Curriculum development in language teaching. Cambridge, U.K. ; New York : Cambridge University Press

20. Richards, J. (2006). 'Materials development and research – Making the connection'. RELC Journal. 37/1:5-26.

21. Rivas, R.M. (1999). 'Reading in recent ELT coursebooks'. ELT Journal. 53/1:12-21.

22. Tomlinson, B. (1998). (Ed.) Materials Development in Language Teaching. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

23. Tomlinson, B. (ed.) (2003). Developing materials for language teaching. Bloomsbury Academic.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Information and Multimedia Technology and English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course covers the application of computers and associated technology for English language teaching, providing an overview of the uses of Computer Assisted Language Learning in schools. Topics include English language teaching software evaluation, interactive instructional technologies, multimedia, the Internet in English language teaching, and English language teaching curriculum applications. The major emphasis is on determining the needs / applications of computers in English language teaching in Hong Kong schools. Participants in the course are provided with hands-on experience in using and evaluating English language teaching software.
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Professional development for CALL teachers; PD groups and activities; CALL journals and references; tools for teachers

2. Language investigation (corpus linguistics, online dictionaries, pronunciation dictionaries; etc.)

3. Teacher language awareness and grammar teaching: capitalizing on technology

4. Teaching Vocabulary , Listening, Speaking, Reading Comprehension; and Writing with technology

5. Projects and their visual presentation Integrating e-learning with Flipped Learning

6. Strategies to develop technology-enhanced learning)

7. Engaging Students inside and outside the classroom for technology-enhanced learning
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: mid-term and/or course-end evaluation questionnaires

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via consultation, e-mail, telephone or face-to-face chat
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Bax, Stephen. 2003. CALL - past, present and future. SYSTEM, Vol. 31, Issue 1, pp. 13-28.

2. Beaty, Ken. 2003. Teaching and researching Computer-assisted Language Learning. Pearson Education: London.

3. Boswood, Tim (ed.). 1997. New ways of using computers in language teaching. TESOL publications: Alexandria, Virginia.

4. Butler-Pascoe, Mary Ellen and Warburg, Karin M. 2003. Technology and teaching English language learners. Pearson Education: Boston: MA.

5. Chapelle, Carol. 2001. Computer applications in second language acquisition. Cambridge University Press: Cambridge.

6. Chapelle, Carol. 2003. English language learning and technology. John Benjamins: Amsterdam.

7. Coniam, David. 1998. The use of speech recognition software as an English language oral assessment instrument: An exploratory study. CALICO Journal, Vol. 15, No. 4, 7-23.

8. Coniam, David. 2004. Using language engineering programs to raise awareness of future CALL potential. Computer Assisted Language Learning, Vol. 17, No. 2, pp. 149-176.

9. Egbert, Joy. 2005. CALL essentials: Principles and practice in CALL classrooms. TESOL publications: Alexandria, Virginia.

10. Gillespie, John and McKee, Jane. 1999. Does it fit and does it make any difference? Integrating CALL into the curriculum. Computer Assisted Language Learning, Vol. 12, No. 5, pp. 441-455.

11. Huang, Shih-Jen and Liu, Hsiao-Fang. 2000. Communicative language teaching in a multimedia language lab. Internet TESL Journal, Vol. VI, No. 2.

12. Jonassen, David H, Peck, Lyle L and Wilson, Brent, G. 1999. Learning with technology. Merrill/Prentice Hall: Upper Saddle River, NJ.

13. Kurzweil, Ray. 2005. The singularity is near. Penguin : London.

14. Leech, Geoffrey and Candlin, Christopher (eds.). 1986. Computers in English language teaching and research. Longman: London.

15. Matusevich, Melissa N. 1995. School reform: What role can technology play in a constructivist setting. (http://pixel.cs.vt.edu/edu/fis/techcons.html).

16. Sperling, Dave. 2000. The Internet guide for English language teachers. 2nd edition. Prentice Hall Regents: Upper Saddle River, NJ.

17. Teeler, Dede with Gray, Peta. 2000. How to use the Internet in ELT. Pearson: .Harlow, Essex.

18. Warschauer, M. & Healey, D. (1998). Computers and language learning: An overview. Language Teaching, Vol. 31, 57-71.

19. Warschauer, M. 1996. Computer-assisted language learning: An introduction. In S. Fotos (Ed.), Multimedia language teaching (pp. 3-20). Tokyo: Logos International.

20. Windeatt, Scott, Hardisty, David, Eastment, David. 2000. The Internet. Oxford University Press: Oxford.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Current Issues in English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course examines recent policy initiatives, curriculum developments, research or key projects in English and / or English language teaching in Hong Kong or overseas. The background and implications of these issues on the teaching and learning of English will be analysed. Ways to address these issues at the school and classroom levels will also be explored.
courses.component:
Discussion
Independent Study
Lecture
Others
Seminar
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:

1. have a basic understanding of the theoretical / contextual backgrounds of the issue(s) being examined;
2. be able to analyse critically the implications of the issue(s) on the teaching and learning of English in general; and

3. be able to apply the input from the course to address the needs in their professional contexts.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of the issues

2. Critical analysis of the issue

3. Pedagogical implications
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: mid-term and/or course-end evaluation questionnaires

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via consultation, e-mail, telephone or face-to-face chat
courses.recommended_readings: Reference materials will focus on the issue(s) being examined in the course.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: English Language Teaching Curriculum Theory and Design
courses.description: The course is designed to develop an appreciation of the central and emergent ideas in curriculum theory as it relates to English language teaching. Students examine the characteristics and assumptions of various types of language syllabuses. The course also critically reviews the processes of syllabus construction (e.g., needs analysis, content selection, sub-division, grading and sequencing) as well as curriculum implementation, management, and evaluation. Case studies of curricular problems in Hong Kong are analysed.
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Curriculum theory and design

2. Hong Kong English Language curriculum

3. Needs analysis in curriculum development

4. Role and design of instructional materials

5. Effective teaching

6. Role and design of English Language assessment

7. Curriculum evaluation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: mid-term and/or course-end evaluation questionnaire

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via e-mail, consultation or face-to-face chat
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Brown, J.D.B. (2001). The Elements of Language Curriculum: A Systematic Approach to Program Development. Heinle & Heinle Publishers.

2. Richards, J.C. (2001). Curriculum Development in Language Teaching. Cambridge: CUP.

3. Nation, P. and Mcalister, J. (2009). Language Curriculum Design. Routledge

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Teaching English Through Language Arts
courses.description: This course examines the place of language arts in the English language curriculum and focuses on methods and techniques through which language arts can be used to enhance students' English language skills within a communicative approach to language teaching and learning. A wide range of genres including drama, novels, short stories, poems, films, songs, etc. will be covered.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Enrichment Activities for English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course introduces a range of language activities that supplement the coursebook and the formal curriculum. Such activities help to enliven the learning experience, provide exposure to authentic language, and create opportunities for communicative language use. Example sources are the mass media, songs and rhymes, communication games, and leisure reading materials. Extra-curricular activities that provide enjoyable learning experiences include drama, debating, publishing, choral speaking, etc.
courses.academic_group: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.academic_org: English Stud & Eng Lang Edu PC
courses.course_syllabus:
1. To introduce course participants to a range of language enrichment activities (LEA).

2. To equip course participants with the professional skills of:

(i) selecting, adapting and designing LEA that suit the teaching context they are in to complement the textbooks and the formal curriculum;
(ii) adopting effective teaching strategies for using LEA to teach English in formal classroom learning context; and

(iii) integrating formal and informal curricular through the use of LEA.

3. To further enhance use of classroom language.

4. To develop generic skills such as creativity, communication skills, interpersonal skills, presentation skills and collaboration skills.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Formal: mid-term and/or course-end evaluation questionnaire

2. Informal: students can channel feedback to the teacher via e-mail, consultation or face-to-face chat
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Lee, I., Lee, M. & Ng, R. (1994). Fun after hours: Extra-curricular activities in secondary schools. Hong Kong: Institute of Language in Education.

2. Man, E., Coniam, D., Lee. I., Bruce, C., Tam, C., Cheung, A. & Chau, A. (2003). Establishing an English-rich environment in EMI schools. Hong Kong: The Chinese University of Hong Kong.

3. Mok, A. (1997). English language enrichment programme resource book. Hong Kong: INSTEP, University of Hong Kong.

courses.subject: ELED
courses.title: Special Topics in English Language Teaching
courses.description: From time to time the Faculty will offer courses that will focus on an area of English language teaching that is not already covered in the regular programme of studies. These topics will reflect professional needs / interests and Faculty expertise as well as addressing new developments in English language teaching in Hong Kong.
